action.content:
You are playing a cooperative negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the sum of your score and the score of the other player.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

1 phone, 2 mirrors, 2 fruits

Your secret value function is:

phone: 4, mirror: 2, fruit: 1

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.
action.label: context

action.content: Hi — I suggest we split so each gets items totaling as many as possible. One reasonable fair split is: you take the phone (most valuable), and I take the 2 mirrors and 2 fruits. That way nothing is left out and we both get value. Are you okay with that, or do you prefer a different split?
action.label: response

action.content: Hi — I suggest we split so each gets items totaling as many as possible. One reasonable fair split is: you take the phone (most valuable), and I take the 2 mirrors and 2 fruits. That way nothing is left out and we both get value. Are you okay with that, or do you prefer a different split?

You are playing a cooperative negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the sum of your score and the score of the other player.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

1 phone, 2 mirrors, 2 fruits

Your secret value function is:

phone: 6, mirror: 0, fruit: 2

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.


Hi — I suggest we split so each gets items totaling as many as possible. One reasonable fair split is: you take the phone (most valuable), and I take the 2 mirrors and 2 fruits. That way nothing is left out and we both get value. Are you okay with that, or do you prefer a different split?
action.label: context

action.content:
That split you suggested works well for total value: I value the phone at 6, mirrors at 0, fruits at 2 each. If you take the phone, and I take the 2 mirrors and 2 fruits, total values are: you 6, me 4, combined 10 — that's optimal since total available value is 6 + 0*2 + 2*2 = 10.

If you'd prefer more balanced individual scores instead of maximizing total, another option is you take the phone plus 1 mirror, and I take 1 mirror and 2 fruits: you'd get 6, I'd get 4 — same as before. Alternatively you could take phone + a fruit (value 8 for you) and I take 2 mirrors + 1 fruit (value 2 for me), which is less balanced.

Do you accept you taking the phone and me taking both fruits and both mirrors?
action.label: response

action.content:

action.label: context

action.content:
I accept that split: you take the phone, and I'll take the 2 mirrors and 2 fruits. 

Secret proposal: [Proposal: 1 phone, 2 mirrors, 2 fruits]
action.label: response

action.content: The other player has submitted a secret proposal. It is now your turn to submit a proposal of your own.
action.label: context
